required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Montelukast in Mild Asthmatic Children With Allergic Rhinitis (0476-367)
clinical_study.official_title: Korean Study of "Real-World" Montelukast Use in Mild Asthmatic Children With Concomitant Allergic Rhinitis

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to assess real-world effectiveness of montelukast in children (2 to 14 years) with asthma and allergic rhinitis.

primary_outcome.measure: Change From Baseline for Daytime Asthma Symptom Score
primary_outcome.description: The score is an ordinal scale from 0 (no symptoms) to 5 (most symptoms). The change was calculated as the score at 12 weeks minus the score at baseline. Thus, a negative value for change from baseline indicates a favorable outcome.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change From Baseline for Daily Allergic Rhinitis Symptom Score
secondary_outcome.description: The score is an ordinal scale from 0 (no symptoms) to 3 (most symptoms). The change was calculated as the score at 12 weeks minus the score at baseline. Thus, a negative value for change from baseline indicates a favorable outcome.

arm_group.description: Participants were treated for 12 months after randomization: Participants 2 to 5 years of age took one 4 mg chewable tablet and 6 to 14 years of age took one 5 mg chewable tablet daily in the evening. If participants had exacerbated from mild to moderate within 12 weeks, inhaled corticosteroids (ICS) was added to Montelukast and ICS, respectively and those participants were excluded in the efficacy evaluation at 12 weeks.

Participants were treated for 12 months after randomization: Each participant's physician selected the ICS agent, dose, and regimen. If participants had exacerbated from mild to moderate within 12 weeks, ICS was added to Montelukast and ICS, respectively and those participants were excluded in the efficacy evaluation at 12 weeks.

intervention.description: Montelukast 4/5 mg tablet (oral chewable), once daily, 12 weeks to up to 12 months
Inhaled corticosteroid solution, 1-4 puffs daily, 12 weeks to up to 12 months

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Between 2 and 14 years old
- Diagnosed with asthma, classified as mild persistent asthma according to Global Initiative Asthma Guidelines (GINA)
- Diagnosed with comorbid allergic rhinitis
Exclusion Criteria:
- Patients with suspected sinus infection
- Prior treatment with high dose inhaled corticosteroid requiring a dose higher than beclomethasone dipropionate 400 ug per day, or equivalent, other medications used in severe cases

participant_flow.recruitment_details: Conducted at 5 sites in Korea, Jan2005~ Oct2007 in pediatric participants with comorbid mild asthma and allergic rhinitis. Participant's caregiver understands the study procedures and agrees to participate, signing the informed consent form.
participant_flow.pre_assignment_details: Up to 1 week for wash-out - prior to baseline randomization.

group.description: Participants were treated for 12 months after randomization: Participants 2 to 5 years of age took one 4 mg chewable tablet and 6 to 14 years of age took one 5 mg chewable tablet daily in the evening. If participants had exacerbated from mild to moderate within 12 weeks, inhaled corticosteroids (ICS) was added to Montelukast and ICS, respectively and those participants were excluded in the efficacy evaluation at 12 weeks.

If participants had exacerbated from mild to moderate within 12 weeks, ICS was added to Montelukast and ICS, respectively and those participants were excluded in the efficacy evaluation at 12 weeks.

group.title: Montelukast
group.description: Participants were treated for 12 months after randomization: Participants 2 to 5 years of age took one 4 mg chewable tablet and 6 to 14 years of age took one 5 mg chewable tablet daily in the evening. If participants had exacerbated from mild to moderate within 12 weeks, inhaled corticosteroids (ICS) was added to Montelukast and ICS, respectively and those participants were excluded in the efficacy evaluation at 12 weeks.

group.description: Participants were treated for 12 months after randomization: Each participant's physician selected the ICS agent, dose, and regimen. If participants had exacerbated from mild to moderate within 12 weeks, ICS was added to Montelukast and ICS, respectively and those participants were excluded in the efficacy evaluation at 12 weeks.

measure.title: Age
measure.description: The primary efficacy parameter was a mean change from baseline to treatment for daytime asthma symptom score. Therefore 138 participants who didn't have a daytime asthma symptom score from the participant diary were not included.

measure.title: Sex: Female, Male
measure.description: The primary efficacy parameter was a mean change from baseline to treatment for daytime asthma symptom score. Therefore 138 participants who didn't have a daytime asthma symptom score from the participant diary were not included.

measure.title: Allergic rhinitis
measure.description: Based on GINA guidelines. The primary efficacy parameter was a mean change from baseline to treatment for daytime asthma symptom score. Therefore 138 participants who didn't have a daytime asthma symptom score from the participant diary were not included.

measure.title: Type of allergic rhinitis
measure.description: The primary efficacy parameter was a mean change from baseline to treatment for daytime asthma symptom score. Therefore 138 participants who didn't have a daytime asthma symptom score from the participant diary were not included.

measure.title: Daily allergic rhinitis symptom score
measure.description: The score is an ordinal scale from 0 (no symptoms) to 3 (most symptoms). 24 participants with baseline scores were included in the Montelukast group and 28 participants with baseline scores were included in the ICS group.

measure.title: Daytime asthma symptom score
measure.description: The score is an ordinal scale from 0 (no symptoms) to 5 (most symptoms). The primary efficacy parameter was a mean change from baseline to treatment for daytime asthma symptom score. Therefore 138 participants who didn't have a daytime asthma symptom score from the participant diary were not included.

measure.title: Duration of allergic rhinitis
measure.description: 24 participants were included in the Montelukast group and 28 participants were included in the ICS group.

measure.title: Duration of asthma
measure.description: The primary efficacy parameter was a mean change from baseline to treatment for daytime asthma symptom score. Therefore 138 participants who didn't have a daytime asthma symptom score from the participant diary were not included.

outcome.title: Change From Baseline for Daytime Asthma Symptom Score
outcome.description: The score is an ordinal scale from 0 (no symptoms) to 5 (most symptoms). The change was calculated as the score at 12 weeks minus the score at baseline. Thus, a negative value for change from baseline indicates a favorable outcome.
outcome.population: The primary efficacy parameter was a mean change from baseline to treatment for daytime asthma symptom score. Therefore 138 participants who didn't have a daytime asthma symptom score from the participant diary were not included.

group.title: Daytime Asthma Symptom Score at Baseline - Montelukast
group.description: Participants received study drug and had efficacy measurements both at baseline and during the treatment period. If participants had exacerbated from mild to moderate within 12 weeks, inhaled corticosteroids (ICS) was added to Montelukast and ICS, respectively and those participants were excluded in the efficacy evaluation at 12 weeks.

group.title: Daytime Asthma Symptom Score at 12 Weeks - Montelukast
group.description: Participants received study drug and had efficacy measurements both at baseline and during the treatment period. If participants had exacerbated from mild to moderate within 12 weeks, inhaled corticosteroids (ICS) was added to Montelukast and ICS, respectively and those participants were excluded in the efficacy evaluation at 12 weeks.

group.title: Daytime Asthma Symptom Score at Baseline - ICS
group.description: Participants received study drug and had efficacy measurements both at baseline and during the treatment period. If participants had exacerbated from mild to moderate within 12 weeks, inhaled corticosteroids (ICS) was added to Montelukast and ICS, respectively and those participants were excluded in the efficacy evaluation at 12 weeks.

group.title: Daytime Asthma Symptom Score at 12 Weeks - ICS
group.description: Participants received study drug and had efficacy measurements both at baseline and during the treatment period. If participants had exacerbated from mild to moderate within 12 weeks, inhaled corticosteroids (ICS) was added to Montelukast and ICS, respectively and those participants were excluded in the efficacy evaluation at 12 weeks.

measure.title: Change From Baseline for Daytime Asthma Symptom Score
measure.description: The score is an ordinal scale from 0 (no symptoms) to 5 (most symptoms). The change was calculated as the score at 12 weeks minus the score at baseline. Thus, a negative value for change from baseline indicates a favorable outcome.
measure.population: The primary efficacy parameter was a mean change from baseline to treatment for daytime asthma symptom score. Therefore 138 participants who didn't have a daytime asthma symptom score from the participant diary were not included.

analysis.groups_desc: Change from BL to Week 12 - Montelukast. The difference in mean change from baseline to 12 weeks in daytime asthma symptom score was tested by paired t-test (H0: difference =0) for the Montelukast treatment group. Subjects in this analysis: N=24 subjects for the within arm (single arm) comparison between BL and Week 12 scores.

Change from BL to Week 12 - ICS. The difference in mean change from baseline to 12 weeks in daytime asthma symptom score was tested by paired t-test (H0: difference =0) for the ICS treatment group. Subjects in this analysis: N=29 subjects for the within arm (single arm) comparison between BL and Week 12 scores.

outcome.title: Change From Baseline for Daily Allergic Rhinitis Symptom Score
outcome.description: The score is an ordinal scale from 0 (no symptoms) to 3 (most symptoms). The change was calculated as the score at 12 weeks minus the score at baseline. Thus, a negative value for change from baseline indicates a favorable outcome.
outcome.population: The secondary efficacy parameter was a mean change from baseline to treatment for daily allergic rhinitis symptom score. Therefore 139 participants who didn't have a daily allergic rhinitis symptom score from the participant diary were not included.

group.title: Daily Allergic Rhinitis Symptom Score at Baseline- Montelukast
group.description: Participants received study drug and had efficacy measurements both at baseline and during the treatment period. If participants had exacerbated from mild to moderate within 12 weeks, inhaled corticosteroids (ICS) was added to Montelukast and ICS, respectively and those participants were excluded in the efficacy evaluation at 12 weeks.

group.title: Daily Allergic Rhinitis Symptom Score at 12 Weeks- Montelukast
group.description: Participants received study drug and had efficacy measurements both at baseline and during the treatment period. If participants had exacerbated from mild to moderate within 12 weeks, inhaled corticosteroids (ICS) was added to Montelukast and ICS, respectively and those participants were excluded in the efficacy evaluation at 12 weeks.

group.title: Daily Allergic Rhinitis Symptom Score at Baseline - ICS
group.description: Participants received study drug and had efficacy measurements both at baseline and during the treatment period. If participants had exacerbated from mild to moderate within 12 weeks, inhaled corticosteroids (ICS) was added to Montelukast and ICS, respectively and those participants were excluded in the efficacy evaluation at 12 weeks.

group.title: Daily Allergic Rhinitis Symptom Score 12 Weeks - ICS
group.description: Participants received study drug and had efficacy measurements both at baseline and during the treatment period. If participants had exacerbated from mild to moderate within 12 weeks, inhaled corticosteroids (ICS) was added to Montelukast and ICS, respectively and those participants were excluded in the efficacy evaluation at 12 weeks.

measure.title: Change From Baseline for Daily Allergic Rhinitis Symptom Score
measure.description: The score is an ordinal scale from 0 (no symptoms) to 3 (most symptoms). The change was calculated as the score at 12 weeks minus the score at baseline. Thus, a negative value for change from baseline indicates a favorable outcome.
measure.population: The secondary efficacy parameter was a mean change from baseline to treatment for daily allergic rhinitis symptom score. Therefore 139 participants who didn't have a daily allergic rhinitis symptom score from the participant diary were not included.

analysis.groups_desc: Change from BL to Week 12 - Montelukast. The difference in mean change from baseline to 12 weeks in daily allergic rhinitis symptom score was tested by paired t-test (H0: difference =0) for the Montelukast treatment group. Subjects in this analysis: N=24 subjects for the within arm (single arm) comparison between BL and Week 12 scores.

Change from BL to Week 12 - ICS. The difference in mean change from baseline to 12 weeks in daily allergic rhinitis symptom score was tested by paired t-test (H0: difference =0) for the ICS treatment group. Subjects in this analysis: N=28 subjects for the within arm (single arm) comparison between BL and Week 12 scores.

If participants had exacerbated from mild to moderate within 12 weeks, inhaled corticosteroids (ICS) was added to Montelukast and ICS, respectively and those participants were excluded in the efficacy evaluation at 12 weeks.

group.description: Participants were treated for 12 months after randomization: Each participant's physician selected the ICS agent, dose, and regimen. certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: Merck agreements may vary with individual investigators, but will not prohibit any investigator from publishing. Merck supports the publication of results from all centers of a multi-center trial but requests that reports based on single-site data not precede the primary publication of the entire clinical trial.

clinical_results.limitations_and_caveats: This was an open-label study. Only 53 patients had diary information with daytime asthma symptom score - thus, 138 cases were dropped from analysis due to lack of daytime asthma symptom score.

point_of_contact.name_or_title: Senior Vice President, Global Clinical Development
